questions.question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)?
questions.explanation: OCD is characterized by persistent intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions) aimed at reducing anxiety

questions.question: In Nestadt et al.'s (2000) study, what was found regarding first-degree relatives of patients with OCD?
options: They have a lower risk of developing OCD
They have a five-times greater risk of developing OCD
They have no increased risk of developing OCD
They have a higher risk of developing depression only
questions.explanation: Nestadt et al. found that individuals with a first-degree relative with OCD had a five-times greater risk of developing the disorder themselves. This corresponds to: They have a five-times greater risk of developing OCD.

questions.question: What is the primary focus of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) in treating OCD?
questions.explanation: CBT for OCD focuses on challenging irrational thoughts and beliefs that contribute to obsessive-compulsive behaviors

questions.question: A patient with OCD is treated using exposure and response prevention (ERP). What is the main goal of this treatment?
options: To prevent the performance of compulsive behaviors
To reinforce avoidance of anxiety-provoking stimuli
questions.explanation: ERP aims to expose patients to their feared stimuli while preventing them from engaging in compulsive behaviors, helping to reduce anxiety over time. This corresponds to: To prevent the performance of compulsive behaviors.

questions.question: Which of the following is a limitation of the genetic explanation for OCD?
options: It does not account for environmental factors
It is the only explanation for OCD
It has 100% concordance rates in identical twins
It is not supported by empirical evidence
questions.explanation: A limitation is that the genetic explanation does not account for environmental factors, as evidenced by the fact that concordance rates are never 100%. This corresponds to: It does not account for environmental factors.

questions.question: According to the two-process model, how does an obsession in OCD typically develop?
options: By associating a neutral stimulus with anxiety
questions.explanation: The two-process model suggests that an obsession develops when a neutral stimulus becomes associated with anxiety, leading to compulsive behaviors. This corresponds to: By associating a neutral stimulus with anxiety.

questions.question: What is a common side effect of drug treatments for OCD?
questions.explanation: Common side effects of drug treatments for OCD, particularly SSRIs, can include nausea among other physical symptoms

questions.question: What methodological issue is associated with studies on the genetic basis of OCD?
options: They rely solely on self-reported data
They do not consider the role of environmental factors
They are conducted only on children
questions.explanation: A methodological issue is that many studies do not consider the role of environmental factors, which can also contribute to the development of OCD. This corresponds to: They do not consider the role of environmental factors.

questions.question: What is the role of serotonin in the biological explanation of OCD?
options: It is always elevated in patients with OCD
It is linked to the development of compulsive behaviors
Low levels of serotonin are associated with OCD
It has no impact on OCD symptoms
questions.explanation: The biological explanation suggests that low levels of serotonin are associated with OCD, leading to the use of SSRIs to increase serotonin levels

questions.question: Which treatment for OCD involves the use of a hierarchy of fears?
questions.explanation: Systematic desensitization involves creating a hierarchy of fears and gradually exposing the patient to these fears while teaching relaxation techniques
